titleStmt.title: M54. [Anon] Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 33p. Fragmentary pagination and not consecutive with the other typescript fragments. On verso of p. 11 unidentified holograph fragment.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54. [Anon] Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 33p. Fragmentary pagination and not consecutive with the other typescript fragments. On verso of p. 11 unidentified holograph fragment.

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: The printing press brought the past into existence.

It brought into existence the man who is conscious of the
pat past
the man who sees his time, zzzzz against a back ground of
the past; the man who firsts sees himself and shows himself
to us. xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmm The first
blow has been aimed at Anon when the authors name is attached

his
mae name is also Harrison. Harrison emerging from the past
tells us that he has a library; that he owns a mastiff;

that he digs up Roman coins. He tells us that he has
nev ben never been
more than forty miles from radwinter in Essex. Anon is
losing his ambiguity. The present is becoming visible.

Harrison sees the pxmxmxmxmsx the present
agains against the

settled
reroded recorded past. The past looks
degnerate degenerate , raw,
against that past.
Upstairs in the great room , as he tells us, "our ancient
ladies of the court" were to be found reading the
Greeks and the Latins. as they sat at their needlework.

And the
sch;ars scholars in the
c ege college library were reading the

classics that were chained to the
shlves shelves in the
college libraries. He turned away from the actors who

even while he dug up
voins coins in his garden were acting their

crude
darams dramas in the market place. Hxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxm
atxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx
wexmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxx Yet in spite of
the printed book and the new learning, the the
common people were still at their lewd practises.
The historians work from the outer to the inner; from the

house they infer the
teant tenant of the house. It is the house
thy they
dwell upon; the chairs and the furniture of the house.

It is as if we were told
nbideen bidden to infer from
a tweed suit, and six hats, and a fox terrier, and a

waljing walking stick and a c kitchen with a
col coal fire and a

servant pcalled perhaps Joan the life and
woks works of a novelist call
hnery jmes Henry James that wrote the
Goldn Golden

and the Ambassadors, Save for
Cahucer Chaucer and Lydgate
and the voice of Anon singing at the back door the English

a race of
me rhcnats merchants , soldiers and
preists priests builders who left behind
thm them
stone houses, cultivated fields and vast cathedrals. but
not no words. The great house is silent; Only the furniture

mains remains , stiff and ornate,
fanastic fantastic and uncushioned.
At Gorhambury for instance Lady Bacon sat at her table
writing letters. But Her letters to her son are letter written [illeg.]
from the pulpit; as intricate involved and formal as state

papers or legal documents or
dyin depositons dying depositions . She admonishes and preaches;
suspicions of her soul. She is a counsellor admonishing a

subordinate. She is aware expressive only of
th the wickedness of
men, the dangers and deceits of the world; and the
awfu;ness awfulness of her God. Greek and Latin come to her pen

as easily as English. If she has to
decend descend to the actual
objec object

a basket of
starwberries strawberries -- it is with
coircomlocution circumlocution and

dark threats. "I have sent them by
th the boy of my kitchen,

l.quote: a shrewd witted boy and prettily cachetized, but yet an

p.l:
untoward crafty boy..." She writes
onlt only to
exhort "God keep us sound in the faith and send us health
and a care to please God above all" Or to admonish---

quote.l: "Be not speedy of speech, nor talk suddenly, but where
discretion requireth, and that soberly then....

Let not Lawson, that fox, be
acqaunited acquainted with my letters..."

p.l:
Fear of man, fear of God surround them as h as with the
wallsof walls of

a dungeon. There is no gaiety, no freedom, no
familairity familiarity

ni in the
hose house she lives in. The sound of the Bible is in her

wars words . Her prose takes its
slolemn solemn strain. And the prose

of the bible will not adapt itself to the
eaxy easy , the
co oqu colloquial
It is a garment to be put on when the mind is erect and

dignified, on state
oaccions occasions .
It is because they use of the prose of the bible when
they write prose that the Elizabethans are unknown to us.

It They can say nothing
simle simple , nothing intimate.

They are
nevr never subtle; they are never shaded. Bright
contrastd contrasted

colours meet on their faces. Carnation and
sanow snow ;
ebony and gold. When we look at them we see them

young
men s men's bodies

are stiffly sewn into
dohblets doublets and school boys faces

are raised above starched collars;
yong young women serve only to s

display heavy quilted
dresse dresses stuck about with huge pearls.

The writer,
to rds towards the end of the
sicteenth cnyury sixteenth century ,

was separate from his
arudience audience ; but he was still closely

connected with it. He was himself unspecialised,
un ifferent undifferentiated
ated. His eye was stimulated by the crimsons and gold and
greens of the clothing. His ear was stimulated by the

sound of words For
ac each word was given substance and sharpness

for coins. When he was walking in xxx the
Arcbishops Archbishop of

Canterburys garden, " the poor come
kkocking knocking at the gate

l.quote: and my man says "Sir, there is some one at the gate would

p.l:
speak with
oyu you ." So he laid aside his book and went
out among the poor. He visited them in their hovels. He
noted their poverty. He saw the poor man unable now
to buy a goose, for the great lords were enclosing the
fields. He went to the great man and found him still in

bed, after his hunting
anf hid and his hawking. He saw the poor
sutis suitors

waiting
ho hour in the hall to get their suit
herad heard .
These were the casees that he brought before King Edward

In a voice that
sumbles stumbles and uses the old language of
his fathers house, ))" they say in my country to the hogs
mingle mangle, cum pur, cum pur"--- he brought into the
light of day the hxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmx
xmxmxmxmxmxxx the harlot going to execution at Newgate

and saying as she went "that
f if good fellows had kept

l.quote: touch with her, she had not bin at this time in that case."

p.l:
He saw the curates in their
velevet velvet shoes and slippers
meet to dance the morris dance. And the fine ladies

dressed in
vardinaglls vardingalls with their hair puffed out in tussocks

He saw the
yo ng young men given over in the s t to gulling
drinm ig drinking
and whoring. The young men dice away their thrift; Instead of

shooting with the long
ow bow they their sports are lost

turned into bowling
drinming drinking and whoring. He And the poor
are still going on pilgrimages, setting up candles and
wirshipping worshipping pigs bones. [illeg.] He casts the light of the new
learning upon the the old superstitions. He too, until he

Anon has emerged
suffievcntly sufficiently from the forests and the
floods to let us see a rough outline of a human shape.
He has a dog and a garden. He has books; and he digs in
the earth. His name is of no great moment. It may be
Harrison; or it may be Paston. There is very little to dis

tingusih distinguish one from the other. He has no
exr ssion expression on his
fae face
He conveys to us chiefly what his eye sees, what his body

feels. He sees
ngland England very clearly. He sees

its
emptines emptiness ; ; he conveys the scarcity of people; the
predominace predominance of individuals. The Queen is the dominant

fogure figure . He can count her
posses ons possessions -- a few ships; a few

great
hous s houses . He watches her
progeresses progresses . She is
parliemtn parliament ,
press, society, law and order. But the man who sees this
the individual, is still cumbered and stiff. Writing is
still an art that requires great ceremony. What you make
with the pen is separate from what you say with the tongue.

Only a few years back words were written
elbaorately elaborately in
lustrous ink upon valuable parchment; and the leaves,
bound together, were chained to the lectern and read,
by a few, in great physical discomfort,

on hard
neches benches in the cold. Even now, when words are printed,
the great public is not the reader, or the paymaster.
Written words must please a single man in the first place,
must find its way into some noble room, where the nobles

and the gentry, have
lisure leisure after hunting, after

seeing their estates, and
contrlling controlling their servants,
to to pick up a book and read its history or sing its song.
For Words must tell stories; or they must sound to
the ear. For the nobles had their music; they played tunes
tunes to the words that the writers wrote.

It is the printing press
th t that disturbs this company.

It is the printing press that makes the writer a
nany many headed

many limbed. a mongrel with so many different
pearants parents

that it requires a
hole whole army of learned men, and a perpetual
provision of fine tasters to keep any order or distinction
etween between the different members. The presses of London,
Ca,bridge Cambridge , sucking in copy, and casting out legible books

that
nany one any one could read was not a nice
fedder [feeder?] . Anything
that could be written could be printed. What Any morality,

any record, whatever men wished
recored recorded , it would deliver

as a book. Unlike the
pa nter painter or the musician the writer
after the birth of the printing press is exposed to

innumerable
inappropirate inappropriate and
irelveant irrelevant
s licitaions solcitations .

Why not write the
hist history of your parish? Or the life of a

Roman emperor? Why not take part in the
governement government of your

country? Why not advise the soul of its
erils perils ? Why not become

pampheleteer pamphleteer
histroain historian moralist, or playwright? The Press is

read to accept anything. And as the
oublic public becomes less
serivile servile , less martial less concerned to keep out the cold
and fight the enemy, as glass is fitted into windows
and pillows replace logs, the public adds its own invitation

to the writer. It is an inquisitive
acti e active minded public;
it soon dissipates and takes hold of Anon. It makes him

into an innumerable
comany company of familiar
sprits spirits , one

pr aching preaching another delighting,
anotherinstructing another instructing . Only a few
still persist into making words into works of art.

thirty "had walked in the shadow of
d ath death ." It was Master

Boilney Bilney at
Ca, fiege [Cambridge?] who
ppened opened his eyes; Master Bilney

who went about among the poor and the
sivk sick ,

Master Bilney heard him preach
agianst against
Melnchton Melancthon and his

opinons. and desired me for Gods sake to hear his
confessio confession

l.quote: "did so; and to say the very truth, by his confession

p.l:
I learnt ed more than for many
yeares yeares . With Bilney he
vi ted visited

the
prisones prisoners in the Tower at Cambridge, for he was ever
visig visiting

pirsoners prisoners
andsick and sick folk. There was a woman who had killed
her child. And brought her story before King
Hnery Henry the eighth as he talked with him after the sermon in

the gallery. and he got her
padrdon pardon . Master Bilney was burnt;

so it may wi be, he will be burnt.
eanehile Meanwhile he will speak

the truth so that the
simp le simple can understand. In their own

tongue. Standing on the verge of the
Elizabetha Elizabethan age,
he saw, as Harrison saw, the great buildings rise on the

foundations of the old. "There
ws was never such buildings then

as
if is now, planting, nor marrying." And yet the
Englis English are

still sunk in
supe stition superstition . Give
thmoey the money he implores that

l.quote:
was wont to bestow on
pilgrimagesmatters pilgrimages matters , in trentalls

p.l: in masses, in purgatory matters" to poor men sons so that

they may become
schlars scholars . "There be now none but greate mens

l.quote: It will come to pass that

quote.l:
we
shallhave shall have nothing but a little
Ebglish English divinity, that will
bring the realm into a very barbarousness, and utter

p.l:
This was the voice of the new
lraning learning , the
vo ce voice

that ousted
superstiti,n superstition , the voice of reason, charity, common

sense. But it was by an
irnoy irony ironically enough, the
The writer then came to birth with difficulty in
England; for so long as familiar letters are written in
Biblical prose there are limits to his freedom; a barrier
between the sayable and the unsayable. He is in being;
for the printing press has given him a name; but still
unspecialised, undifferentiated. The artist is not wholly
write writer , wholly musician, or wholly painter. It seems
possible that the great English art may not be the art of
words. His eye is stimulated by the colour of the

of the
clotning clothing , of the pageantry. his ear by the sound of

words spoken aloud. For books were read aloud. "
Prtitachrd Pritchard " wrote Lady Ann Clifford

l.quote:
"read aloud the Faery Queen..... They read aloud
Montage Montaigne

p.l: and the Faery Queen." Every word was given sharpness and
substance by the speaking voice. And the lute, the cithern,
the old full bodied instrument that still stands on a

ches chest ,
hgave gave lilt, rhythm, melody to the word.

quote.l:
"Hardly one lighter or boat in
hree three that had the goods
of a house in it , but there was a pair of virginals in

p.l: it" Pepys observed in 1666 when the people of London were
loading their goods onto boats to escape from the fire of

London. His mind the was full of undifferentiated words,
ole old
words and new words; French and Latin. No grammar bound them
tightly together. They were elastic; they could be danced to
and sung to. But they could not follow the pace of the
spea ing speaking voice.
Spenser then in the Faery Queen is like a

half articulate monster rising from the depths of
silnce silence
hung with the weeds and pearls of the deep sea in

by the speaking voice. And the
l tes lutes and the
cithersn citherns

have gave lilt and
rhym rhythm and melody to the spoken word.

His mind was full of half sung half
spoekn spoken words;

full of undifferentiated words;
ol old words, new words; French words
Latin words. No grammar bound them tightly together.

They were elastic. They could stretch to any
lgneth length . They
cd could

could
refelct reflect many colours; they could
fol ow follow many tunes,
they could be danced to, and sung to. But they could not
follow the words of the speaking voice. For a moment then

there is a pause on the threshold of the
gre t great
lizabethan Elizabethan
room. The artist is not wholly writer, wholly musician, or

wholly
paineter painter . xmxsxmxsmssxmxsxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxsxmxmxmxmxmxmmx

xmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxm.
Sahekeapere Shakespeare may be
Michael Michelangelo

Angelo;
Soenser Spenser may be Pergolesi. It seems possible that the
great English art may not be the art of poetry.
the preacher who was for banishing Robin Hoodand such

supersitions superstitions was forging the very weapon
theat that give the old
mibstrels minstrels a new lease of life. His English. When he
said the Lords prayer at the beginning and at

theend of his
ermon sermon he was putting English intpo high places.
He was rescuing it from the back door. He was teaching

Spenser and
Shakespere Shakespeare how to write.
Both Harrison and Latimer see the very same house [The house was being?]

the
hose house thatwas being built on the foundations of the
old house. We can still see the great Elizabethan house
whose building was to both preacher and antiquary a
sign of txmxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx luxury. in all its glory.

There it is, standing in its green island of Park
seapareted separated

often from the high road by only a
d p dip in the ground and a

low red wall. With its
congloeration conglomeration of roofs and chapels

and
chimeys chimneys
i it dwarfs its
neighboyrs neighbours . Inside all is kept as

if the Queen Elizabeth were expected. The upright
Elizabetahn Elizabethan

chairs stand round the walls. Their
ftinges fittings and tapestry
are not much faded. The great oak tables are heavy

and polished. The
carbed carved chairs and cupboards look
barnd brand
new. The floor is strewn with carpets; cut glass chandeliers

hang down from the decorated
pl ter plaster work on the
celing ceiling .

Even knick knacks
ha v have survived; the inlaid work box,

the and the pear shaped
l te lute on which the Queen once
played.
But the Elizabethans themselves are silent. Only
the furniture remains,, stiff and ornate, fantastic and
uncushioned uncushioned .
he the writer hsa been so long submerged. We cannot read

the
aery Faery Queen; nor leave it
undread unread . It is a poem
without a plot; the metre, casting its regular fling of

sound, comes to ground
to too evenly, too solidly, unlike
Chaucer who goes on, simply, directly, at an even pace.
Great groups, composed, arranged, come together with the

orest forest for
back rg und background . Spenser must have seen Italian
pictures; or was it natural then to make compositions even

in words? The
Knihgyts knights the
ldaies ladies and the ogres
pass away amble their way through the glades and become

one with the clouds. Like a
lcliund [cloud?] the words move up and

down;
furst first lulling the ear then cloying the ear.
It has the sweetness of a dream; something cut adrift from

the rough
rish Irish land which lay outside; it has freshness,

it has
csharpness sharpness . It is the thing itself;
it is the original design, from which Tennyson and
mad made their copies.
Latimer heard them. He raged.

Latimer had read the
Lord Lord's Prayer in English. The Bible
was printed in English. And, using the prose of the bible

when they write prose, the
Elixabethans Elizabethans are
unknwon unknown to us.
When in some extremity of anguish or fear they take up the

pen they use the
rhyms rhythms of the Bible.
Itis It is a garment only

to be worn when the mind is in the right
attidtue attitude . They can

say nothing simple, subtle, or
breif brief . At
Gorham nury Gorhambury Lady
Ann Bacon sat writing to her son. But her letters are like

seroms sermons , or
satte doucments state documents , intricate, involved,
circumtutious. She is a counsellor admonishing a subordinate;

She
e hosrts exhorts God keep us sound in the faith

l.quote: and send us health and a care to please God before all."

p.l: She admonishes Be not speedy of speech, nor talk

l.quote:
suuddenly suddenly ,
discrteion discretion
requieth requireth and that

p.l: soberly then..." If she has to descend to an actual object

a basket of
starwberries strawberries it is with c dark
insintuat ons insinuations .

Greek and
atin Latin come as easily to her pen as

English. There is no
gaity gaiety , no freedom no
familairty familiarity

in this world. Fear of God,
suspciion suspicion of man surround

the writer as with the
wlls walls of a dungeon. The wall may

conceal a Lady Ann
whois who is merry and gay; it may conceal

must
cobneceal conceal passion, laughter and sorrow;
but no one can tell who it is that lives on the other side

of the wall of formal
langauge language .
